In this study, we demonstrate that applying a nitrogen-doped carbon coating to nickel (Ni@NC) improves its durability for converting levulinic acid (LA) into γ-valerolactone (GVL) through hydrogenation. Various characterization techniques revealed that the carbon structure is porous, with nickel being highly dispersed and embedded due to a strong interaction between the nickel and carbon framework. Catalytic tests for LA hydrogenation were conducted at temperatures ranging from 200 to 260 °C under atmospheric pressure, with different weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) values. The Ni@NC catalyst was found to be optimal, achieving 88% conversion of LA and 100% selectivity for GVL at 240 °C with a WHSV of 1.14 h-1. This catalyst maintained a high GVL yield and excellent long-term stability for 100 hours under conditions of WHSV of 2.28 h-1 at 260 °C and atmospheric pressure. In contrast, the Ni/g-C3N4 catalyst, prepared using the impregnation method, produced a good GVL yield but exhibited poor stability under the same conditions. These findings suggest that catalysts with strong metal-support interactions can potentially improve stability. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Levulinic acid Nickel Hydrogenation γ-valerolactone Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Reducing fossil fuel use and greenhouse gas emissions can be achieved by incorporating renewable biomass into the chemical industry [1]. Converting lignocellulosic biomass into chemicals and fuels using catalytic processes with different catalysts is essential for decreasing society's reliance on fossil resources [2]. Levulinic acid (LA), a significant platform compound, has been produced from both C5 and C6 sugars through the use of acid-based catalysts [3,4]. The catalytic hydrogenation of LA to synthesize γ-Valerolactone (GVL) offers an effective route for producing fuel additives and platform chemicals [5–7]; GVL can also be converted into various long-chain alkanes [8], 1,4-pentanediol [9,10], methyl tetrahydrofuran [11], and pentanoate esters [12]. Precious metals like Au, Ru, and Pt are essential in the selective production of GVL from LA. These catalysts exhibit a high selectivity for GVL. However, their high cost and limited availability pose significant challenges for large-scale industrial applications. Researchers are actively exploring alternative catalysts that can match or exceed the performance of precious metals while being more economically viable. Recent studies have shown promising results with transition metal-based catalysts, such as nickel and copper, which offer a balance between catalytic activity and cost-effectiveness [13,14]. Consequently, there is a need for highly stable, more active, and non-noble metal catalytic systems for biomass upgrading, particularly for hydrogenation reactions [15–17]. The LA hydrogenation into GVL can be accomplished through the use of either batch reactors or fixed bed reactors [18,19]. Batch reactors are advantageous for their adaptability to various reaction conditions, making them ideal for smaller-scale production [20]. In contrast, fixed bed reactors facilitate continuous operation, making them more appropriate for large-scale industrial use. In recent years, Wang et al. introduced a Ni/Ru bimetallic ordered mesoporous carbon catalyst designed for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. Under mild conditions, a nearly complete yield of GVL was obtained using 2-propanol as a solvent at a low reaction temperature of 80 °C over a period of 4 h [21]. Tang et al. described the use of Ni-Zn non-noble bimetallic catalysts, which are supported on ordered mesoporous carbon, for the hydrogenation process to produce GVL from LA in an aqueous environment. Using the bimetallic NiZn@OMC catalyst, a GVL yield of 93 % was achieved at 180 °C in 1.5 h [22]. Kantam et al. presented a Ni/Organoclay catalyst for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL [23]. When LA was hydrogenated using this catalyst at 140 °C and 3 MPa for 4 h, it achieved a complete conversion of LA and a full selectivity for GVL. Mohan et al. reported that the hydro cyclization of LA to GVL over supported Ni catalysts showed significant productivity at 250 °C in vapour phase conditions [24]. In a fixed bed reactor operating at atmospheric pressure, various transition-based catalysts were explored for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. Nickel-based catalysts have been extensively investigated for their role in the valorization of biomass-derived platform molecules such as γ-valerolactone, levulinic acid, and glycerol. Typically, nickel-based catalysts are effective in activating and hydrogenating levulinic acid molecules. However, deactivation of nickel occurs due to its susceptibility to oxidation, sintering, and leaching during the reaction process. In recent times, several research teams have been investigating photocatalytic H2 evolution reactions [25], which serve as a source of H2 for the LA hydrogenation process [26–28]. Herein, we report a simple and highly stable nickel catalyst coated with nitrogen-doped carbon (Ni@NC), which demonstrates high efficiency in LA hydrogenation. The carbon's highly porous nature facilitates the extensive distribution of nickel, with the nickel particles being enveloped by a robust interaction with the carbon framework. In this study, a Ni-based catalyst with high dispersion was effectively created using a simple in situ pyrolysis technique, utilizing dopamine as both the complexing agent and the carbon source. The carbon layer was in situ formed around Ni NPs, thus preventing Ni particles from migration, aggregation and oxidation by air. The results underscore the promise of Ni@NC catalysts for large-scale GVL production from biomass-derived LA, presenting a sustainable method for enhancing the value of renewable resources. Additionally, in-depth characterization of the catalyst structure and surface properties could provide valuable insights for the rational design of next-generation catalysts. The optimization of reaction conditions could further enhance the efficiency of the GVL production process. The in situ pyrolysis technique employed in the catalyst's synthesis, using dopamine as both a complexing agent and carbon source, represents an innovative approach to creating highly dispersed Ni-based catalysts. The catalyst's structure, featuring nickel particles encased in nitrogen-doped carbon, leverages the carbon's porosity to achieve extensive nickel distribution. This arrangement not only enhances the catalyst's performance but also protects the nickel particles from migration, aggregation, and oxidation. Future studies should focus on exploring the scalability of the Ni@NC catalyst system and its applicability to other biomass-derived platform molecules. 2 Experimental The textural properties have been determined by Quanta-chrome Novae 2200 instrument by using a Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm. Before the analysis, the catalysts were degassed for 6 h at 300 °C. The surface area was determined by the multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and the pore volume and pore size were calculated by BJH method. The textural properties were measured at −196 °C by the BET method, taking 0.0162 nm2 as its cross-sectional area. The H2-TPR analysis was done by using the BEL-CAT-II MICROTRAC instrument. Approximately 0.05 g of the sample was placed inside a U-shaped quartz tube. Before conducting the TPR studies, the catalyst sample underwent pretreatment by exposing it to a flow of He gas at 200 °C for one hour. Once the pretreatment was complete, the sample was allowed to cool to room temperature, and the analysis was performed in a 5 % H2 -Ar flow while the temperature was increased from room temperature to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C per minute. Using a Thermo K-Alpha Plus spectrometer with a monochromated Al-Kα source, the chemical states of two separate Ni catalysts were analyzed through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The Debye-Scherrer method was employed to determine the crystallite sizes of reduced Ni (111) and NiO (200). The XRD patterns of the synthesized catalysts were examined using a Rigaku Smart Lab SE with Cu Kβ radiation at 40 kV and 45 mA, scanning at a speed of 5° per minute. The surface morphology of the catalysts that were prepared was examined using a scanning electron microscope, specifically the Carl Zeiss Supra 55, with an accelerating voltage of 5.00 kV, as well as a High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope, the JEOL JEM 2100. Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was conducted using the Agilent model 5110. 2.1 Materials 2.1.1 Preparation of Ni@NC Dopamine (0.8 g) was dissolved in deionized water before the addition of aqueous nickel acetate solution under magnetic stirring within 10 min. Subsequently, TRIS [tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane] buffer was introduced into the mixture, and the solution was continuously stirred for 24 hours at room temperature. The resulting product was obtained through filtration and then dried in an oven set to 80 °C for 30 min. The solid was subsequently placed in a tubular furnace and subjected to annealing in a nitrogen atmosphere at 650 °C for 3 h, following a heating rate of 3 °C/min. The nanocomposites produced were designated as Ni@NC. Additionally, a nitrogen-doped carbon sample (NC) without nickel was prepared using the same method, omitting the nickel acetate. 2.1.2 Experimental procedure Catalytic experiments were performed at atmospheric pressure using a fixed-bed reactor constructed from quartz glass, measuring 14 mm in diameter and 300 mm in length. The catalyst particles were combined with an equal amount of quartz particles and positioned at the reactor's center. To ensure that the reactant vaporized before coming into contact with the catalyst, a layer of silicon beads was positioned above the catalyst bed to act as a preheating zone, maintaining a temperature of 240 °C. Before conducting the test, the catalyst was reduced at 400 °C for 2 h in a stream of H2. The liquid feed (LA) was continuously introduced using a syringe feed pump, accompanied by a flow of H2. The products were gathered in a trap cooled with ice and examined using a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionisation detector (FID). The conversion and selectivity were calculated as follows: LA conversion ( % ) = Levulinic acid conversion in feed − Levulinic acid in sample Levulinic acid in feed × 100 GVL Selectivity ( % ) = GVL produced LA converted × 100 3 Results and discussion Ni@NC catalyst has been synthesized by one pot synthesis involves polymerization of dopamine in the presence of Ni ions and subsequent carbonization of resultant Ni-Polymer complex. In this preparation, dopamine acts as a carbon and nitrogen source. Based on ICP analysis and elemental analysis (Table 1 ), the Ni fraction in Ni@NC is 12.1 wt. %. and the nitrogen content in Ni@NC is 9.0 wt. %. XRD patterns of as-prepared NC and Ni@NC samples are shown in Fig. 1 . In the Ni@NC, XRD peaks are detected at approximately 2θ= 37.3°, 43.3°, and 62.9° in 3.1 (a), which can be attributed to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) diffraction patterns of the typical face-centered cubic crystalline NiO (JCPDS-ICDD No. 78–0429) [29,30]. In addition, the Ni@NC sample shows two prominent diffraction peaks at 44.6° and 52.3°, which correspond to the (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) crystal planes, respectively. This is attributed to metallic Ni, resulting from the partial reduction of NiO to Ni during the pyrolysis process [31]. Ni@NC sample has been reduced under 5H2/Ar flow at 400 °C for 2 h and reported in Fig. 1b In addition, the disappearance of the NiO peaks after reduction of the samples indicated that NiO is completely reduced to metallic Ni. The reflection peaks for Ni in the reduced Ni@NC catalyst were much more distinct than those in the Ni@NC catalysts, indicating that the Ni particles were larger. The average size of the crystallites of Ni in the reduced Ni@NC sample is determined using the Scherrer equation: d = 0.9k/(b cosθ), where d represents the particle size, k is the X-ray wavelength, b denotes the full width at half maximum (FWHM), and θ is the peak's center angle. The Ni particle size is found to be 15.1 nm. The BET isotherms for NC and Ni@NC catalysts were measured to characterize their textural properties and displayed in Fig. 2 . (a & b). Fig. 2b illustrates the pore size distributions for both catalysts, which were determined using the BJH method applied to the adsorption branch of the isotherm. Table 1 presents a summary of the BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter. The Ni@NC isotherm is classified as type IV, characterized by a rapid rise in adsorption at low relative pressures, followed by a pronounced hysteresis in the adsorption/desorption cycle at higher relative pressures (P/Po-0.4), as depicted in Fig. 2a. This behavior suggests the existence of mesopores [32]. The NC material possesses a specific surface area of 441 m2/gm and a pore volume of 0.494 mL/gm. The isotherms for Ni@NC exhibit a pronounced increase at low relative pressure (P/P0 < 0.015) and display a hysteresis loop at a relative pressure of 0.4, indicating the presence of numerous micropore and meso/macropore structures within the material. The Ni@NC exhibited a specific surface area of 373 m²/g and a pore volume of 0.235 mL/g. Compared to the NC sample, the Ni@NC sample had a smaller specific area and featured a more limited pore size distribution. When subjected to pyrolysis at high temperatures in an inert environment, the Ni-dopamine complex transformed into nitrogen-doped porous carbon, while the embedded Ni species were simultaneously anchored by the nitrogen elements. Fig. 3 showed the structural morphology of NC and Ni@NC catalysts. NC sample show a structural morphology consisting of spherical particles of approximately similar size and shape Fig. 3a. In the case of Ni@NC sample, morphology has changed to non-spherical shape and merged together. The incorporation of nickel into the carbon matrix appears to have significantly altered the structural characteristics of the material. This transformation likely results from the interaction between nickel particles and the carbon framework during the synthesis process. The observed changes in morphology may have important implications for the catalytic performance of Ni@NC compared to the pristine NC sample. Fig. 4 shows that Ni@NC sample consist of Ni, N, C and O elements. Fig. 4b shows that Ni particles are uniformly distributed over the carbon support. The Ni crystal morphologies and associated particle size distributions (PSDs) of the reduced catalysts are investigated by scanning transmission microscopy (STEM), and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . It was observed that more uniform distributions and smaller particles of the Ni nanoparticles existed in the Ni@NC catalysts and the average particle size is around 18 nm. This is in good agreement with the crystallite size of 15.1 nm obtained from XRD analysis. The improved dispersion and reduced particle size of Ni in the Ni@NC catalysts are due to the nitrogen-doped carbon support, which fosters strong interactions between the metal and the support [33]. This enhancement in dispersion and particle size results in a greater surface area of active Ni sites, which may lead to increased catalytic activity. Additionally, the even distribution of Ni nanoparticles indicates a more uniform and dependable catalytic performance throughout the catalyst surface. The chemical properties of the as-synthesized catalysts were further studied by XPS characterization (Fig. 6 ). The Ni@NC sample displays C1s peaks located around 284.6 eV, with a broad peak indicates the existence of various carbon species in the sample. The C1s spectrum can be deconvoluted into several distinct components, each corresponding to a different carbon-bonding environment (CC, CN and CO bonds) [34]. The O1s XPS peak is observed at approximately 532.1 eV [35,36]. The reduced catalyst shows two major peaks at binding energies (BE) of 852.8 and 869.7 eV corresponding to the core level Ni 2P3/2 and Ni 2P1/2 transitions respectively [37–39]. Some part of the Ni in the catalyst might have undergone surface oxidation during the sample transfer in the XPS chamber resulting in yielding two shoulder peaks at binding energies (BE) of 858 and 874 eV in the XPS pattern [40]. The N 1 s spectra could be deconvoluted into three distinct peaks corresponding to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, and pyridinic N +-O-species [41–43]. H2-TPR analysis was conducted to examine the reducibility of NiO in the prepared sample (Fig. 7 ). The Ni@NC exhibited reduction peaks at 235.5 °C and 244 °C, which are linked to the reduction of NiO on the outermost surface. The peak at 445 °C in Ni@NC is associated with the reduction of NiO due to its relatively strong interaction with nitrogen-doped carbon, as a result of NiO particles being trapped within the mesopores of the nitrogen-doped carbon. In contrast, nitrogen-doped carbon without Ni did not display any reduction peak, owing to the absence of Ni. 3.1 Catalytic activity The catalytic efficiency of NC and Ni@NC catalysts in the LA hydrogenation process was assessed at a WHSV of 3.42 h-1, a temperature of 240 °C, and a hydrogen pressure of 0.1 MPa (Table 2 ). The catalyst screening studies were evaluated using a relatively high concentration of levulinic acid solution (30 % aqueous LA) in contrast to most previous studies that used a highly diluted LA solution to assess the effectiveness of the screening for industrial applications. Nickel is commonly acknowledged as the most efficient catalyst for converting LA into GVL through hydrogenation. The main objective of this research was to develop a durable nickel-based catalyst that can selectively hydrogenate LA to GVL in an aqueous phase. GVL is produced through LA hydrogenation and dehydration via two potential pathways [44,45]. The first involves hydrogenating LA to γ-hydroxypentanoic acid (HVA), then dehydrating it to γ-valerolactone. The second dehydrates angelica lactone before hydrogenation to GVL. Angelica lactone synthesis requires higher temperatures and acidity than γ-hydroxypentanoic acid. Under milder conditions, the HVA pathway is more common for GVL production. The LA conversion over bare NC was found to be relatively low at just 8 %. Ni particles, combined with NC, converted 33.1 % of LA into GVL, proving that Ni particles act as active hydrogenating sites. The presence of nickel in the carbon support may also facilitate the adsorption and activation of hydrogen molecules, further enhancing the hydrogenation process. Additionally, the porous structure of the nitrogen-doped carbon likely provides a high surface area for the reaction to occur, increasing the overall efficiency of the catalyst. These factors combined contribute to the superior performance of Ni@NC in the conversion of levulinic acid to GVL compared to bare NC. The catalyst synthesized from one pot synthesis method showed better activity due to the availability of nickel active sites, which are perfectly anchored in the mesopores of NC. Recent advancements in heterogeneous catalysts have shown promise in increasing GVL yields, paving the way for more sustainable production methods. In the case of Ni@gC3N4 sample, the conversion of LA is 41.2 %, while the selectivity of GVL is 91 %. The results revealed that the Ni@NC catalyst exhibited superior performance compared to the NC catalyst, achieving a higher LA conversion rate and GVL yield. This enhanced catalytic activity can be attributed to the synergistic effect between the nickel nanoparticles and the nitrogen-doped carbon support. Subsequent temperature experiments were conducted between 200 °C and 260 °C to determine the ideal thermal conditions that maximize GVL yield while reducing the production of by-products and the results are illustrated in the Fig. 8 . The findings indicated that as the reaction temperature increased from 200 °C to 260 °C, the conversion rate of LA progressively rose from 8 % to 47.1 %. Meanwhile, the selectivity for GVL also steadily raised from 92 % to 100 % at 240 °C and then declined to 08 % at 260 °C. At temperatures below 220 °C, the conversion rate of levulinic acid to GVL was significantly slower, resulting in lower yields. Conversely, temperatures exceeding 240 °C led to an increase in undesirable side reactions, producing valeric acid and reducing the overall GVL yield. As temperature rises, formation of by-products involving C–C bond breaking increases, suggesting the hydrogenolysis capability of the Ni@NC catalyst is temperature-dependent. Within this optimal temperature range, the highest GVL yield was achieved at 240 °C. The reaction kinetics at this temperature provided the ideal balance between conversion rate and selectivity towards GVL formation. The influence of weight hour space velocities (WHSVs) on the yield of products using the Ni@NC catalyst was investigated by altering the space velocities under optimal conditions (260 °C, 0.1 MPa). As depicted in Fig. 9 , the results for LA conversion suggest that the activity diminishes with increasing WHSV due to reduced residence times. To assess the catalyst's efficiency beyond equilibrium conversion values, we evaluated its stability under specific conditions: WHSV-2.28 h-1, a temperature of 240 °C, and a hydrogen pressure of 0.1 MPa. Initially, the Ni/gC3N4 catalyst showed impressive results, achieving a 72 % conversion of LA and 100 % selectivity for GVL. Meanwhile, the Ni@NC catalyst achieved a 57 % LA conversion with the same 100 % selectivity for GVL under these conditions. As depicted in the Fig. 10 , the LA conversion for Ni/gC3N4 gradually decreased from 72 % to 32.1 % over a 57-hour period. In contrast, the Ni@NC catalyst maintained stable LA conversion and selectivity throughout the entire duration of the test. The gradual decline in its catalytic activity of Ni@gC3N4 over time suggests potential issues with catalyst deactivation or sintering of Ni nanoparticles. The superior performance of Ni/gC3N4 in the initial stages can be attributed to its unique structural properties and enhanced metal-support interactions. In their study, Putra et al. showed that Cu/ZrO2 and Cu/SBA-15 catalysts hydrogenated LA to GVL at 265 °C under 1 atm H2 pressure. During the 50-hour stream test, both catalysts deactivated rapidly [46,47]. Sato et al. found that Cu-Ni/Al2O3 exhibited the highest GVL productivity. However, the catalyst experienced gradual deactivation over time when subjected to high space velocity conditions, primarily due to the sintering of the supported metals [48]. Mitta et al. demonstrated that the Cu/HTC catalyst resulted in an 87.5 % conversion rate of LA and a 95 % selectivity for GVL when tested at 265 °C under a hydrogen pressure of 1 atm. A stability test was conducted under ideal conditions on the catalyst [49]. The reported catalyst deactivated quickly after 18 hours on stream. A recent study found that the Cu/OMC catalyst exhibited exceptional performance, achieving full LA conversion and 98 % GVL yield. Remarkably, its effectiveness remained consistent even after 60 hours of continuous testing under optimal conditions [50]. The enhanced catalytic performance of Ni@NC can be attributed to the synergistic effect between Ni particles and the nitrogen-doped carbon support. This synergy likely improves the dispersion of Ni particles and enhances their stability during the reaction. Furthermore, the nitrogen-doping in the carbon support may contribute to the overall catalytic activity by modifying the electronic properties of the catalyst surface. This catalyst achieves a high yield of GVL with excellent long-term stability under the given conditions. In comparison, the Ni/g-C₃N₄ catalyst, prepared and tested for LA hydrogenation, shows considerably poorer stability under the same conditions. The high activity and stability of Ni@NC is because of fine particle size of highly dispersed Ni particles. Dopamine undergoes oxidative self-polymerization under alkaline and aerobic conditions to form polydopamine, which can chelate Ni²⁺. Further heating under inert atmosphere, polydopamine decomposes to form a N-doped carbon layer, while chelated Ni²⁺ gets reduced to Ni nanoparticles, often encapsulated by the resulting carbon (From STEM, Fig. 5). TEM imaging of the spent catalyst to confirm the structural changes of the catalyst was examined. The TEM images and corresponding histograms are displayed in the Supplementary Information. It is clearly shown that the particle size of the spent catalyst is almost as fresh catalyst. The uniformity of particle size distribution between fresh and spent catalysts suggests minimal sintering or agglomeration during the reaction process. These findings suggest that catalysts with robust metal-support interactions have the potential to enhance stability. Table 3 The catalysts mentioned demonstrated enhanced performance at elevated temperatures and lower concentrations of LA, typically around 10wt %. The Ni@NC catalyst, in particular, showed the greatest catalytic efficiency, achieving complete LA conversion and 98 % GVL selectivity at 240 °C under atmospheric H2 pressure, attributed to its extensive surface Cu area. This remarkable performance can be attributed to the synergistic effect between nickel and the nitrogen-doped carbon support. The nitrogen-doping not only enhances the dispersion of nickel particles but also modifies the electronic structure of the catalyst, leading to improved adsorption and activation of the reactants. Furthermore, the high temperature and low LA concentration create optimal conditions for the reaction, minimizing side reactions and maximizing GVL yield. 4 Conclusion A facile in situ pyrolysis method was successfully used to synthesize a highly dispersed Ni-based catalyst, where dopamine was used as the complexing agent and carbon source. "A carbon layer was formed in situ around Ni nanoparticles, effectively preventing the migration and aggregation of Ni particles. At 240 °C with a WHSV of 1.14 h-1, Ni@NC achieved an 88 % conversion rate of LA and complete selectivity for GVL. High nickel dispersion and carbon encapsulation enhance LA hydrogenation catalytic performance, resulting in high GVL yields. Furthermore, Ni@NC's activity remained the same after 100 hours of operation, possibly due to the protective carbon layer encasing it. The catalyst's stability and longevity make it a promising candidate for industrial applications in the production of GVL from LA. CRediT authorship contribution statement G. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we demonstrate that applying a nitrogen-doped carbon coating to nickel (Ni@NC) improves its durability for converting levulinic acid (LA) into γ-valerolactone (GVL) through hydrogenation. Various characterization techniques revealed that the carbon structure is porous, with nickel being highly dispersed and embedded due to a strong interaction between the nickel and carbon framework. Catalytic tests for LA hydrogenation were conducted at temperatures ranging from 200 to 260 °C under atmospheric pressure, with different weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) values. The Ni@NC catalyst was found to be optimal, achieving 88% conversion of LA and 100% selectivity for GVL at 240 °C with a WHSV of 1.14 h-1. This catalyst maintained a high GVL yield and excellent long-term stability for 100 hours under conditions of WHSV of 2.28 h-1 at 260 °C and atmospheric pressure. In contrast, the Ni/g-C3N4 catalyst, prepared using the impregnation method, produced a good GVL yield but exhibited poor stability under the same conditions. These findings suggest that catalysts with strong metal-support interactions can potentially improve stability.
